awd_titl_txt: Conference: Funding for Student and Young Scientist Attendance at the 16th International Solar Wind Conference Series
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Solar Wind Conference series is a triennial event that brings experts from around the world to discuss the latest research and advancements in the field of solar wind physics and the connections between the solar wind and other space-environments. Over the past fifty years, the conference has grown in size and scope, attracting scientists from a wide range of disciplines, including solar physics, heliophysics, space physics, and planetary science. The conference has also evolved to include sessions on cutting-edge topics such as solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and space weather, providing opportunities for interdisciplinary interactions between professionals working on various aspects of space physics research.  This project supports students and young scientists to attend the 16th International Solar Wind Conference Series to be held June 12-16, 2023 in Asilomar, California. 

The Solar Wind 16 conference has compiled a diverse set of selected topics that comprehensively cover the vast field of space physics and solar wind science. The conference brings together experts and researchers from various disciplines to discuss and present the latest advancements and research findings in the field. From the origin and acceleration of the solar wind to its impact on the heliosphere and planetary environments, the selected topics encompass a wide range of themes that reflect the multidisciplinary nature of the field. The chosen topics promise to foster engaging discussions and collaborations among the attendees and contribute to the advancement of space physics research. The topics and proposed sessions are: i. Fundamentals of Solar Wind Physics; ii. Heating and Acceleration of the solar wind ; iii. Solar Wind Interactions; and iv. The “Big Picture”. The NSF funds will be distributed among students and early career scientists as stipends to cover their registration, lodging and/or travel expenses. This budget will allow for a significant number of students and young scientists to attend the conference, providing them with the opportunity to present their research, network with their peers, and learn from established experts in the field. This investment in the next generation of scientists will help to ensure the continued growth and success of the solar wind research community and additionally provide an opportunity to support diversity and inclusivity within this community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This proposal sought funding for students and young scientists to attend the 16th International Solar Wind Conference Series. The funds were distributed among students and early career scientists as stipends to cover their registration, lodging, and/or travel expenses. This budget allowed a significant number of students and young scientists to attend the conference, providing them with opportunities to present their research, network with peers, and learn from established experts in the field. This investment in the next generation of scientists helped ensure the continued growth and success of solar wind research and additionally supported diversity and inclusivity in the community.

Accomplishments

The goal of this proposal was to provide funding for students and early career scientists to attend the conference, in order to expose them to the latest research and developments in the field and to provide opportunities for networking and professional development. A total of 27 students and early career researchers were subsidized within the scope of this proposal, and therefore the main objective was achieved.

Significant Results

A total of 27 students and career students were invited to participate. The level of funding for each participant differs depending on the stated necessities in the registration form. Figure 1 shows the different levels of support given to the participants.

Figure 1. Bar chart showing the level of support given to the different participants of the Solar Wind 16 workshop.


The participants had the opportunity to socialize their work during the oral or poster sessions. The participants were given oral slots unless the participant requested a poster presentation. Figure 2 shows the distribution.





The participant abstracts have been invited for inclusion in the proceedings of the SolarWind 16 workshop. This publication will be featured in the American Institute of Physics (AIP) Conference Proceedings, providing a valuable platform for sharing our research with a broader scientific community.

List of Contributions

Andrea Larosa

The interplay between magnetic switchbacks and solar wind turbulence in the inner heliosphere

Arya Afshari

Observations of Wave-Particle Interactions Leading to Dissipation of Turbulent Energy in Magnetosheath Plasma

Benjamin Alterman

Mass-per-Charge Depending Heating of Iron at a Collisionless Shock

Cecilia Mac Cormack

Sol0HI Living catalogue

Chaoran Gu

Moving-Window Cross-Correlation for the analysis of heavy ion signatures in solar wind and Interplanetary Coronal Mass

Chen Shi

Evolution of weak MHD turbulence in the expanding solar wind: anisotropy, residual energy, and intermittency

Dinesha Hegde

Magnetohydrodynamic Modeling of the 2018 August 20 Slow Coronal Mass Ejection and Solar Wind Interaction

Etienne Berriot

Evolution of the Heliospheric Current Sheet during a PSP-SolO radial alignment

Jack McIntyre

Processes underlying the variation of the magnetic field spectral index in the inner solar wind

Jesse Coburn

Measurement of the rate of change of the electron heat flux with Solar Orbiter observations

Joshua Goodwill

Proton and electron heating near reconnection sites: pressure strain analysis

Matthew Bracamontes

ASHI: The All Sky Heliospheric Imager: August 22-26, 2022, NASA Balloon Flight Image Data Reduction Analysis

Matthew Lennard

Understanding the Complexity of Photospheric Flux Emergence with Machine Learning Techniques

Max McMurdo

Phase mixed Alfven waves in partially ionised plasma

Nikos Sioulas

Higher-Order Analysis of Three-Dimensional Anisotropy in Alfvenic Turbulence

Magnetic field spectral evolution in the inner heliosphere

Roger Scott

Simulation of Thermal Nonequilibrium Cycles in the Solar Wind

Rohit Chhiber

Anisotropic Magnetic Turbulence in the Inner Heliosphere—Radial Evolution of Distributions Observed by Parker Solar Probe

The Influence of Eddy Viscosity and Turbulent Electric Field on Global Solar Wind Modeling

Sailee M. Sawant

Driving the SEPCaster Model with an Automated Solar Active Region Identification and Characterization Module

Samantha Wallace

Characterizing the in situ observed solar wind at L1 from differing source regions

Santiago Pinzon-Cortes

Ring Current Local Time Dependence using Dst index proxies

Tarik Mohammad Salman

Investigation of Interplanetary Coronal Mass Ejection Features: First Insights from PSP Observations

Vishal Upendran

Solar wind signatures in the chromosphere

Solar wind forecasting and source region inference using interpretable deep learning

Winry Ember

Quantifying the Effects of Electron Shot Noise on a Current Biased Antenna

Yihong Wu

Simulations of type II solar radio bursts

Zesen Huang

New Observations of Solar Wind 1/f Turbulence Spectrum from Parker Solar Probe


Last Modified: 06/21/2024
Modified by: Juan Carlos Martinez Oliveros
